awd_titl_txt: Recent Advances and New Directions in  the Interplay of Noncommutative Algebra and Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This NSF award supports participation in the international conference 
``Recent Advances and New Directions in the Interplay of Noncommutative 
Algebra and Geometry,'' which is planned for July 13–17, 2020, at the 
University of Washington in Seattle, Washington.  It is expected that 
80–100 participants from all over the world will attend.  Mathematics 
is the study of patterns. Frequently, such patterns are described via 
systems of equations.  Systems of polynomial-style equations and their 
solutions play a critical role in almost every scientific field, such 
as statistical mechanics, elementary particle physics, quantum mechanics, 
robotics, crystallography, and networking. Often, the solutions cannot 
be found by experimentation, and often they are not numbers but are 
functions (e.g., differential operators or matrices), and so, in general, 
they do not commute. The field of noncommutative algebra is the science 
behind seeking methods that find all solutions to any system of 
polynomial-style equations in noncommuting variables, and the planned 
conference will focus on recent research activities that use different 
types of geometric techniques in noncommutative algebra. The conference 
will consist of survey talks, research talks, a poster session, a career 
panel, a public lecture, and research discussions. The research talks 
will feature 50-minute, 25-minute, and 10-minute lectures in order to 
accommodate researchers at various career stages. The 10-minute talks 
and poster session will take place early in the conference in order to 
facilitate maximal discussion time during the conference between 
early-career researchers and senior researchers. Funding will be 
prioritized for junior participants and for researchers from groups that 
are traditionally under-represented in the mathematical sciences.

The purpose of the planned conference is to generate new research in 
noncommutative algebra and related areas, while contributing to the 
development of the research workforce in noncommutative algebra. This 
major international conference will cover several topics of active 
current interest in noncommutative algebra, with broad connections to 
combinatorics, geometry, mathematical physics, number theory, and topology. 
It will emphasize recent exciting developments and emerging future 
directions, particularly in such areas as noncommutative algebraic geometry, 
Artin-Schelter regular algebras, Calibi-Yau algebras, Hopf algebras and 
quantum groups, category theory, and homological techniques. The conference 
will bring together the leading experts from different specialties within 
noncommutative algebra, encouraging interactions between participants 
from a broad range of perspectives and approaches.  Further information 
can be found at the conference website: https://sites.google.com/view/ndna2020/home

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A week-long international conference ``Recent Advances and New Directions in the Interplay of Noncommutative Algebra and Geometry'' held at the University of Washington, Seattle, from Monday to Friday, June 20--24, 2022, provided a forum for international experts in noncommutative algebra to survey the state-of-the-art in research and to exchange ideas on promising future directions of research. The conference focused on recent developments and new directions in noncommutative algebraic geometry, quantum groups and Hopf algebras, noncommutative invariant theory, and tensor triangular geometry. The primary goals of the conference were to bring together experts in several fields of mathematics with a focus on applications to, or applications of, noncommutative algebra and geometry, to increase cross-pollination between disciplines using similar tools and studying similar objects, to provide young researchers and mathematicians from groups typically underrepresented in the mathematical sciences an opportunity to present their work to a broad audience and to learn about the work being done by established members of their fields, and to give young researchers, especially graduate students, a chance to learn from senior faculty about the process of securing, and retaining, long-term employment in academia.  The co-organizers of the conference were Ken Brown, Tim Hodges, Ron Irving, Michaela Vancliff, and James Zhang. 

 

There were three introductory/survey talks on Monday June 20, 2022 given by Julia Pevtsova on ``Tensor Triangular Geometry in Representation Theory'', Daniel Rogalski on ``Artin-Schelter Regular Algebras'', and Ellen Kirkman on ``The Invariant Theory of Artin-Schelter Regular Algebras''. Twelve other leading experts gave 50-minute talks during the conference. Graduate students and early career researchers were encouraged to give short talks and/or to present their posters.  The conference also hosted several career development and social events to help support young mathematicians. On the afternoon of June~23, Daniel Rogalski led a panel discussion on academic careers and applying for jobs. We discussed a number of topics, ranging from how to apply for postdoctoral, and tenure-track, positions, which items areimportant to hiring committees, advice on how to divide one's time in academia between teaching and research, and so on. The speakers and attendees were diverse in age, gender and research area, and the conference provided fertile ground for collaboration and discussion between researchers who otherwise may not have interacted to this degree. Numerous breaks were also provided, with refreshments, which helped create a relaxed atmosphere for attendees to speak informally to one another about their research. A member of the local chapter of the Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM)organized an AWM dinner aimed at fostering connections between women in the various subdisciplines represented at the conference. Finally, as is typical at such events, a conference dinner was organized at the University of Washington and attended by the vast majority of the conference participants. The Proceedings of this conference will be published by the American Mathematical Society as a volume of the Contemporary Mathematics series. 

This NSF grant, together with some funding from other sources, allowed the conference to fund travel and lodging for most ofthe graduate students, junior faculty, and mathematicians from groups typically underrepresented in the mathematical sciences.
